comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stryi "From October 1914 to May 1915 the city was occupied by the Russian Empire. In 1915 a bloody World War I battle took place in the Carpathian Mountains, around the peak of Zwinin (992 metres above sea level), a few kilometres south of Stryi in which some 33,000 Russian soldiers perished."

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The railway station seems to be rebuilt since then: www.panoramio.com/photo/30803342

comment.author: 33659611@N04
comment._content: Old Polish city, after II World War in Ukraine. Polish dwellers were deported to Siberia (1939 - 1941) what meant death for many of them, Jews were closed in ghetto  and killed in the concentration  camp in Bełżec in 1943. 'Stryj' is very old name which means 'struga' in Polish, 'struga' means English 'stream'.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thank you swanq, B-59 and jelon71 for the details about Stryi. We will add more to the image description when we update,
